text: I'm joined by the justice secretary Mike
will go welcome to you as just his
secretary and as a parliamentarian what
are your reflections on Joe Cox did you
know her at all
I didn't know Joe well but I was
fortunate enough to meet her in almost
her first week in the House of Commons
when we were in the in the same queue in
the Collins Tea Room and she'd forgotten
her cache at that point so I I'll enter
a five-pound note to get ahead of
teammates of money I'm at that time and
did you get it back
absolutely I'm struck up a conversation
with her at the time and had a few
subsequent conversations and she is as
so many people who knew her far better
than me have said an amazing and
wonderful person she's the she's a very
vivid parliamentarian wasn't she yes she
she spoke with great passion and
effectiveness she campaigned for causes
she believed in with you know with with
a great heart and I think she was the
sort of person whom all of us would
would want odd you know our daughters to
grow up to be like she was an amazing
person and I I can only grieve for her
and in particular think of her her poor
children and her bereaved husband and
they're in I know the thoughts and
prayers of many of us at this time now I
don't know whether you have locusts over
this as justice secretary but what's
your view on the debate we've been
talking about already on this program
about security for MPS I know all of you
want to be out there on the front line
meeting your constituents without anyone
in between but there is an issue now a
lot of female MPs in particular yes I've
become worried about the threats
physical threats rape threats since I've
made against them regularly on social
media and Twitter people listen to these
threats and sometimes occasionally
tragically they act on them well you're
absolutely right there there are
colleagues in particular female
colleagues being subjected to the most
horrendous abuse on social media outlets
like Twitter and I think of Lucy an
aperture the again incredibly impressive
and brave Labour MP who has faced them
horrendous anti-semitic abuse Stella
Creasy again a great campaigner and my
colleague Nicky Morgan who has also been
on the receiving end I do think we need
to pause and take a couple of steps back
and reflect on what we can do in order
to ensure that people in the public eye
are kept safe but I say to other things
it's really important that members of
parliament remain acts
guessable as Niklas zooms in Kate Harry
said earlier we are public servants we
are there to be in touch and to reflect
what our voters want us to argue for and
therefore I think that we mustn't try to
hermetically seal MPs away from the
people whom we serve and whom we
represent and I'd say one other thing as
well there are other public servants who
run daily risks and as just a secretary
I think of prison officers those who
work in our court system and police
officers as well you know while I've
been just a secretary there have been
horrendous assaults against prison
officers and of course there's been the
murder of a police officer as well and
Merseyside so forget them
I don't forget absolute leave it there
are so many dedicated public servants
whose hard work we needed to honor and
whose safety needs to be in the
forefront of our mind
Sir Nicholas erm said a moment ago that
the tone of the debate political debate
in this country has been become more and
more aggressive and perhaps excessive as
well do you think I mean the course of
this referendum debate we all want
robust political debate with what
arguments put clearly and robustly and
people to accuse each other of
legitimate things but it has become a
little bit over the top has it not you
wouldn't you know people on both sides
have been pointing the finger in
accusing each other of being traitors
and lying and all the rest of it has it
been a little bit too aggressive if you
think well I think that of course there
have been moments when individuals have
said things that um I I certainly
wouldn't endorse but I'm very strongly
in favor of free speech I think one of
the things that is central to a healthy
democracy is the belief that people can
express themselves and express deep
feelings with passion and force and I
think that one of the things not just
about this referendum campaign but about
election campaigns and big political
choices is that people need to hear the
arguments laid out and the advocates
should be given a fair run and I
certainly think that there have been
people on the remain side and on the
leave side who have made powerful
impressive and passionate arguments and
I think that when we think about what's
precious in our democracy and it is our
democracy that will be will be voting to
to decide on on Thursday when we think
about what is
in our democracy then free speech robust
debate that's at the heart of of our
country our democratized you don't think
it's turn it's gone too far in some
glucose I mean Sadiq Khan who knows a
thing or two about robust debates has
been talk about the climate of hatred
poison negativity and cynicism which he
puts down party to the last few weeks
well I first of like Maher Sadiq I think
that he is proving to be in his first
few weeks a good mayor of London and I
entirely understand after having been
through a mayoral campaign why Sadiq
will reflect on politics in that way but
I take a slightly different view and my
view is that instead of commenting
commentating on the campaign it is the
responsibility of people like myself in
any campaign to make arguments I
entirely respect the right of
commentators people like yourself Andrew
and others to draw conclusions and to to
mark our homework as it were but I don't
think that we politicians should mark
our own homework I think it's important
for us to outline what we believe and
then let the people make a judgement I
don't think I dare mark your homework
Michael go but can I ask you for
instance and it was not your poster but
that famous poster which went out just a
couple of days ago from from the UK side
of the roof of the evening which had a
big crowd of of migrants in fact not
coming to Britain gay on the Slovenian
border most of them brown skinned and he
just said breaking point what do you
think about that kind of rhetoric well
when I saw that poster I shuddered i I
thought it was the wrong thing to do now
again I must stress I believe in free
speech I don't want to deny anyone a
platform when I've had the opportunity
to talk about migration during the
course of this debate I hope I've been
very clear I am Pro migration but I
believe that the way in which we secure
public support for the continued
benefits that migration brings and the
way in which we secure public support
for helping refugees in need is if
people feel that they can control the
numbers overall coming here in Canada
and Australia to countries I very much
admire they have control and therefore
they're able both to welcome economic
migrants and refugees I absolutely
understand that but
let me put you what the vote leaves
statement said on Turkey since the
birthrate in Turkey is so high we can
expect to see an additional million
people added to the UK population from
Turkey alone within eight years crime is
far higher gun ownership and so forth
that sounds a bit like that's the other
those are the threats those people out
there are you could totally happy with
the tone of that kind of statement yes
because I think it's important to stress
that when we're thinking about the
enlargement of the European Union it's
the official European Union policy to
accelerate turkeys accession to the EU
and a number of politicians including
Teresa may have said that at the moment
they don't think that's right in
particular am I in the course of this
debate have pointed out the president
earlier the the president of Turkey has
been taking his country in a direction
which I don't think is progressive or
absolutely true but within eight years
when the prime minister says that Turkey
won't be a member of the EU until the
year 3000 well I think that the fact
that both the British government and the
European Union want Turkey and other
countries to join is clear nobody denies
that the rate and speed at which turkey
will join will depend on a variety of
political factors but it is the case
that during the course of this year the
European Union have made it clear that
they want to accelerate that process and
I think when Turkey's becoming less
democratic that's not the right thing to
do but talking about things like birth
rates even if it doesn't make you
shudder does it make you a little queasy
no I think it's very important when
we're talking about migration to take
into account numbers overall as well and
one of the things about numbers as as
you were discussing with Jeremy is that
we benefit from migration if the numbers
are controlled and we know that when
Romania and Bulgaria joined the European
Union there were predictions on either
side about the numbers of people who
would come and those people at the
higher end of the estimates were correct
and I think that as you discussed what
will happen again a strain on public
services and it's important when we're
thinking about migration to to look at
numbers and to make sure that there is a
balanced approach Michael Heseltine
wrote you a letter in which he said the
brexit case relies on fanning fears
about immigration I'm
amazed that someone like you that he
thought about you marches to the drum of
Faraj Trump and lepen well I hugely
admire Michael Heseltine and the immense
contribution that he's made to do to
Britain's national life but I I don't
think that our campaign is as he
characterizes I think that our campaign
which I'm a stress is a cross-party
campaign which has the support of people
like Frank Field and Cait Harry from the
Labour Party and people like David Owen
who's an independent social democrat is
a campaign that's been characterized
actually by the breadth of voices they
the people he mentions and not the
people who have been you know leading
the leave campaign it has been people
like Kate Frank g√©za the Stewart David

not cut from the cloth that Michael
refers to thank you very much let's move
on to the economic side of the argument
if we may now what what is going to
happen is inevitably some kind of a
gamble even if you say that the Treasury
is kind of warnings are far too extreme
and that some of the stuff we've heard
from other organizations about arming
economic Armageddon are going way way
over the top nonetheless going from
where we are now to a new place does
involve a jolt you've talked about bumps
in the road Michael Howard has said he
doesn't know what's going to happen
after we vote to praxis so for all those
people watching were really worried
about their jobs maybe listening to
their bosses saying be very careful I
want to keep investment in this country
and I'm not sure of whether I will
surely you have to accept that is a
gamble they will be taking if they vote
to leave I wouldn't use the word gamble
no but I do want to be absolutely clear
and direct about this whether we vote to
leave or remain there are risks to our
future there are challenges in the
global economy my view is that those
challenges will be easier to meet those
risks will be less if we vote to leave
because we will have control of the
economic levers we'll have control over
money that we currently sent to the
European Union we'll have control over
our own laws and as a result we'll be
able to deal with whatever the world
throws at us because the people making
decisions on our behalf are people who
are emotionally invested in our future
not people in Brussels or in Strasburg
who are making decisions based on
other factors millions of people are
casting around perhaps to vainly for
some kind of unimpeachable authority but
if you're working for Hitachi whose
bosses have said that if we vote to
leave they will look again at investment
in this country or rolls-royce the same
thing or John Lewis or indeed JP Morgan
who are threatening jobs in in the West
Country they are there to listen to
their own bosses aren't and rightly so
those are the people who know about
their own their own industries their own
case what's striking is that there are
so many bosses and corporate leaders
who've said that whatever happens they
will continue to invest in this country
because the the educational achievements
the generosity of spirit the hard work
and the creative genius of the British
people makes them believe in this
country but more than that there have
been a number of very important business
people antony Bamford one of our leading
industrialists Sir James Dyson a great
magician and drove the Euro of course he
was but he's learnt from experience and
he and Antony Bamford and Simon Wolfson
the chief executive of our great
regional company next all of them are
very clear that we would be better off
if we left the European Union so now if
you if you wouldn't use the word gamble
about taking the choice to leave and it
is a big change in our national destiny
in the national with the way we've been
organising things it's a big big change
what words would you use I think that
what it would be would be an affirmation
of faith and hope in Britain and I think
that Britain would be taking its place
alongside countries like Australia
Canada and New Zealand and America as a
self-governing democracy democracies one
of the great gifts that we gave the
world and other countries which emulated
our approach have prospered and that is
a wonderful thing and I think that if we
voted to leave what we would be doing
we'd be saying that the British people
in their in their wisdom and in their
generosity have the ability to not just
govern themselves well but to be a
progressive beacon to the world
now you mentioned Australia there that
is part of the Australian point system
or immigration is part of what now looks

prophesies about lots of different
you've listed bills that yes European

which would be beneficial to this

Union so absolute that we can't remove
vit if you voted to leave that is
something that we could do and I think

the very poorest in our society but it
is this as it were on the ballot paper
people voting to leave the EU should

people voting to leave you should know

say David Prime Minister here here are

and also the booster to the National

he believes that leaving the single

if he stayed on as Prime Minister as you

absolutely not one of the things it's a

of the things about the Prime Minister
is that he is a Democrat and a patriot
to his bootstraps um when we had a vote

as a Democrat and as a patriot respected

had given on
occasion the Prime Minister if we vote

Conservative MPs including yourself said
we would vote it down in the House of
Commons if it came to that
well I'll how could he have authority as

said that I didn't think the situation
would arise I think that George has been
an outstanding Chancellor and I think
that leaders rescues I mean think I
think he has rescued our economy from
the difficult circumstances that we
inherited in 2010 of course during the

remain side will make political

but it doesn't in any way remove my

that cabin I explained that I didn't
think that the situation would arise I
believe he won't do it well I think that
the the argument that was made was that
on the basis of a speculative report
that the country might lose a
significant amount of money if we were
to leave I think that speculative report
was wrong I think that our economy would

big manipulation of figures in the

if we leave the EU for the political
unity of the party we definitely need to

completely disagree with Alexander

earlier I'm a free speech guy um I

as Chancellor I also think our economy
would be stronger if we voted to leave
we
able to spend the hundreds of millions

it's like a small hamster you're a
